The strong force acts directly upon elementary particles and indirectly upon hadrons through a residual force transmitted by gluons.

The strong force, although only acting directly on elementary particles, is observed as a residual force between hadrons, such as the nuclear force between nucleons in atomic nuclei. This indirect action is mediated by gluons, which are part of the virtual pi and rho mesons that classically transmit the nuclear force. Free quarks, the elementary particles affected by the strong force, have not been directly observed due to color confinement
The force between nucleons is the residual of the strong force, also known as the nuclear force.
Nuclear forces are transmitted indirectly through the exchange of gluons, which are a part of virtual pi and rho mesons, as the strong force acts indirectly between hadrons due to color confinement.
The term for the lack of observable free quarks is color confinement.

The exchange of heavy W and Z bosons creates the weak force, which is responsible for beta decay and associated radioactivity with a field strength 1013 times weaker than the strong force but stronger than gravity over short distances.
The observable effect of W and Z boson exchange is beta decay and associated radioactivity, which is the most familiar effect of the weak force due to the exchange of heavy W and Z bosons.

Beta decay results in radioactivity and is the most familiar effect of the weak force, which is due to the exchange of heavy W and Z bosons. The field strength of the weak force is 1013 times less than that of the strong force.
The weak force has a field strength some 10^{13} times less than that of the strong force.
Weak and electromagnetic forces appear indistinguishable at temperatures in excess of approximately 1015 kelvins, as described in a consistent electroweak theory that shows their equivalence.

The repulsive force of close range atom interaction is Pauli repulsion, due to the fermionic nature of electrons causing repulsion when their electron clouds overlap. This force contributes to the normal force, which is responsible for structural integrity and responds to external forces pushing on solid objects.
Pauli repulsion, due to the fermionic nature of electrons, occurs when electron clouds overlap from different atoms.
Pauli repulsion is caused by the fermionic nature of electrons, resulting in repulsive forces of interaction between their overlapping electron clouds.
The normal force is the force that causes rigid strength in structures.
Ideal strings, with the properties of being massless, frictionless, unbreakable, and unstretchable, can be used to model tension forces.
Ideal pulleys are used to let ideal strings switch direction.

Ideal strings transmit tension forces instantaneously in action-reaction pairs, with any force directed along the string by one object accompanied by a force directed along the string in the opposite direction by the other object. (Tension forces can be modeled using ideal strings that are massless, frictionless, unbreakable, and unstretchable.)
The tension force on the load increases, but the work required to move the load also increases, resulting in the conservation of mechanical energy.

Connecting the same string multiple times to the same object through the use of movable pulleys can increase the tension force on a load. For every string that acts on a load, another factor of the tension force in the string acts on the load.
Newton's mechanics initially described how forces affect idealized point particles.
Newton's mechanics did not afffect extended objects with flowing lattice holding together atoms, which is described by continuum mechanics for situations with changing shape due to forces.
Extended fluids. Pressure differences in these fluids cause forces to be directed along pressure gradients.

A force on one part of an object may affect other parts of the object with extended structure, particularly in materials with flowing lattice holding together the atoms, as described by continuum mechanics in situations where differences in pressure result in forces being directed along pressure gradients.

Newtonian mechanics does not directly address the extended structure and forces that act on parts of an object, which is addressed by the theories of continuum mechanics for situations where matter has the ability to change shape due to forces on its lattice holding together atoms.

Stress, which is calculated using the stress tensor that includes both pressure and shear terms, causes strain (deformation) in structures. Pressure terms arise from forces acting normal to the cross-sectional area, while shear terms result from forces acting parallel to the area. Both tensile stresses and compressions contribute to strain.

The relevant cross section area for calculating volume stress is specified by the context in which the stress tensor is being applied. This area is where the forces acting on the object are being considered, and it can vary depending on the direction and type of stress being analyzed. The stress tensor includes both normal (pressure) and parallel (shear) forces acting on this cross section.
The matrix diagonals of the stress tensor are associated with normal forces that act normal to the cross-sectional area.
The stress tensor includes pressure terms when calculating the relevant cross-sectional area for volume.
Force is to linear momentum as torque is to angular momentum, with torque being the rotational equivalent of force.

No external unbalanced torque would change the rotational inertia of a body under Newton's First Law of Motion. Rotational inertia ensures that a body maintains its angular momentum unless acted upon by an unbalanced torque, similar to how an object at rest stays at rest or in motion with a constant velocity unless acted upon by a net force.

To calculate instant angular acceleration of a rigid body, you would use Newton's Second Law of Motion in its rotational form, which relates unbalanced torque to instant angular acceleration and rotational inertia. The equation is τ = I α, where τ is torque, I is rotational inertia, and α is angular acceleration.
Centripetal force acts perpendicular to the velocity vector and is directed toward the center of the curving path. It does not change the speed of the object but only its direction.
Centripetal forces act perpendicular to velocity vectors, changing only the direction of motion, not its magnitude.
The force that changes an object's direction of travel is the unbalanced centripetal force, which is directed toward the center of the circular path.
Radial force is another term for centripetal force. (Note: This is true in the context of circular motion, where the centripetal force is directed radially inward.)

The tangential force is responsible for speeding up or slowing down an object. The unbalanced centripetal force, which is directed toward the center of the curving path, only changes the direction of the object's velocity vector.

Kinetic energy, as a conservative force only allows for conversion between kinetic and potential forms of energy in a closed system. Therefore, potential energy can only change into kinetic energy in such a system.
Potential energy, for a closed system with a conservative force, is the only form kinetic energy can change into.
In a closed system of conservative forces, net mechanical energy is conserved.
The conservative force between two locations is related to the difference in potential energy in space.
The conservative force between two locations in a potential field is related directly to the difference in potential energy.

For certain physical scenarios, it is impossible to model forces as being due to gradient of potentials because of macrophysical considerations that yield forces as arising from a macroscopic statistical average of microstates, such as friction.

Some forces, such as friction and nonconservative contact forces like tension and compression, cannot be modeled as gradients of potentials in certain physical scenarios due to macrophysical considerations that result in forces arising from a statistical average of microstates. This is because these forces are independent of any macroscale position vector, despite being caused by the gradients of numerous microscopic potentials between atoms. However, for a detailed

Electrostatic gradient potentials create friction at the macroscopic level, as the gradients of numerous electrostatic potentials between atoms contribute to this force. However, the model for friction is independent of any macroscale position vector.
Tension, compression, and drag are nonconservative forces.
Nonconservative and conservative forces are described with statistical mechanics through a detailed treatment in macroscopic closed systems.

Nonconservative forces in macroscopic closed systems change internal energies and can result in energy transformations from ordered to more random conditions as entropy increases, often associated with the transfer of heat.
The exchange of heat is associated with nonconservative forces in macroscopic closed systems, as they often result in energy transformations that increase entropy and lead to a transfer of heat.

The Second law of thermodynamics is associated with closed system heat exchange and states that nonconservative forces result in energy transformations within closed systems from ordered to more random conditions as entropy increases. This often involves the transfer of heat.

Nonconservative forces in a closed system make energy changes by changing the internal energies of the system and transferring heat, resulting in energy transformations from ordered to more random conditions as entropy increases, in accordance with the Second law of thermodynamics.
The metric counterpart less commonly used than the newton is the kilogram-force (kgf) or kilopond.
The kilogram-force is sometimes referred to as a kilopond.

The very seldom used unit of mass in the metric system is the metric slug (also known as mug or hyl), which is defined as the mass that accelerates at 1 m/s^2 when subjected to a force of 1 kgf (kilogram-force).
The seldom used term for a unit of force equal to 1000 pounds-force is the sthène (shēn).
The seldom used force unit equal to one thousand newtons is the sthène (sh).
